com.ojcoleman.ahni.nn
Class BainNN

java.lang.Object
  com.ojcoleman.ahni.nn.NNAdaptor
      com.ojcoleman.ahni.nn.BainNN
All Implemented Interfaces:
Activator, XmlPersistable
public class BainNN
extends NNAdaptor

Provides an interface to Bain neural networks to allow integration with the ANJI/AHNI framework.

Bain neural networks are not well suited to feed-forward networks as every neuron and synapse must be activated every simulation step. Bain is intended for recurrent networks, however the implementations of Activator.nextSequence(double[][]) and Activator.nextSequence(double[][]) are optimised to provide amortised performance over the number of input sequences for layered feed-forward networks.

Constructor Detail

BainNN

public BainNN(com.ojcoleman.bain.NeuralNetwork nn,
              int[] inputDimensions,
              int[] outputDimensions,
              int stepsPerStep,
              BainNN.Topology topology)
       throws java.lang.Exception
Create a new BainNN with the given Bain neural network.

Parameters:
nn - The Bain neural network to use.
inputDimensions - The size of each dimension in the input, see Activator.getInputDimension(). At the moment only one or two dimensional input vectors are supported, so this array should only be of length one or two accordingly. Dimensions should be in the order x, y.
outputDimensions - The size of each dimension in the output, see Activator.getOutputDimension(). At the moment only one or two dimensional output vectors are supported, so this array should only be of length one or two accordingly. Dimensions should be in the order x, y.
stepsPerStep - The number of simulation steps to perform in the Bain neural network for each call to next(..) or nextSequence(..) methods. For feed-forward networks this should be equal to the number of layers. For non-layered feed forward networks this value will be calculated automatically, the supplied value will be ignored.
topology - Specifies the network topology, see topology.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

BainNN

public BainNN(com.ojcoleman.bain.NeuralNetwork nn,
              int[] inputDimensions,
              int[] outputDimensions,
              int stepsPerStep,
              BainNN.Topology topology,
              java.lang.String name,
              int maxCycleLength)
       throws java.lang.Exception
Create a new BainNN with the given Bain neural network.

Parameters:
nn - The Bain neural network to use.
inputDimensions - The size of each dimension in the input, see Activator.getInputDimension(). At the moment only one or two dimensional input vectors are supported, so this array should only be of length one or two accordingly. Dimensions should be in the order x, y.
outputDimensions - The size of each dimension in the output, see Activator.getOutputDimension(). At the moment only one or two dimensional output vectors are supported, so this array should only be of length one or two accordingly. Dimensions should be in the order x, y.
stepsPerStep - The number of simulation steps to perform in the Bain neural network for each call to next(..) or nextSequence(..) methods. For feed-forward networks this should be equal to the number of layers. For non-layered feed forward networks this value will be calculated automatically, the supplied value will be ignored.
topology - Specifies the network topology, see topology.
name - A name for this BainNN.
maxCycleLength - When determining if this network is recurrent, the maximum cycle length to search for before the network is considered recurrent. Note that this is set to the smaller of the given value and number of neurons in the network.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

getInputDimension

public int[] getInputDimension()
Returns:
dimension(s) of input array. If the input array is a single dimension vector then the returned array will have length 1; in general the returned array will have as many elements as there are dimensions in the input vector.

getOutputDimension

public int[] getOutputDimension()
Returns:
dimension(s) of output array. If the output array is a single dimension vector then the returned array will have length 1; in general the returned array will have as many elements as there are dimensions in the output vector.
